data.name: Half Prices
data.description:
Half Prices

You probably know about finding a shortest/cheapest path in a directed, weighted graph. Well, in this kata you are given tickets that let you travel an edge at half-price. Use those tickets the best you can and return the minimum cost of a path from start to finish. ![example graph with minimum path with 1 ticket](https://i.stack.imgur.com/531zD.png) More elaborately, your task is to write the function ```javascript halfPrices(n, edges, r) ``` where - n: the number of vertices in the graph (they are undestood to be the numbers 0, 1,..., n-1) - edges: an array of the edges of the graph. Edge is given as array of 3 numbers: start vertex, end vertex and cost. The costs will always be positive even integers. - r: the number of tickets you are allowed to use (note: you don't need to necessarily use them all, if that gives a cheaper price). You can only use one ticket for one edge (that is, no 1/4-prices etc. Note: as the prices are even, you don't need to worry about floating point numbers, everything will always stay an integer.) The starting vertex is 0 and target vertex n-1. In the tests there is always quaranteed to exist some path between them, so the result will always be finite. --- PS. If you like, you can use an implementation of a PrioritySet which you have as preloaded. You can use it like this: ```javascript var s = new PrioritySet(); s.push('a', 4); s.push('b', 5); s.push('c', -Infinity); s.push('d', 1); s.pop(); // --> 'b' s.reprioritize('c', 10); //element to reprioritize must be in the set, otherwise throws an error s.pop(); // --> 'c' s.remove('a'); //--> true s.pop(); // --> 'd' s.pop(); // --> null s.isEmpty(); // --> true ``` You can also find the code from github
